ffDescription: Nilgiri Tahr, the state animal of Tamil Nadu is the endangered wild goat found in the majestic Nilgiri hills of the spectacular Western ghats. Nilgiri Tahr is the only Tahr which can sustain in a wet tropical environment. The Eravikulam National park is home to a large number of Tahr population. The physical features of this sole mountain ungulate in South India are amazing. The coarse fur, curved horns and 'saddlebacks'(a light grey area on the back of an adult male Tahr) are their unique attributes. The Nilgiri Tahr falls under 'endangered' category of IUCN Red list because of the multitude of threats faced by   them including extreme habitat fragmentation, poaching etc

Neelakurinji (blue flower), scientifically named Strobilanthes Kunthiana that blooms once
 in 12 years,  is a rare species of shrub that naturally thrives on the mountain ranges
 of Munnar. When Neelakurinji blooms, its fascinating purplish-blue color wraps the 
mountains. This flower belongs to the Plietesials species. Notice, Neelakurinji's next 
flowering is in 2030, and don't miss it.

Resplendent shrub frog, scientifically named  Raorchestes Resplendent, is a 
bright-colored frog with reddish-orange. It is a critically endangered species, included
 in the IUCN red list, only found in less than 3sq km on the Anamudi peaks of 
Eravikulam National Park, Munnar, belongs to the Rhacophoridae family. Human 
encroachment and lack of significant care affected its population.

Nilgiri martens are found exclusively in the grasslands and forests of the incredible
 Nilgiri hills of Western ghats. They are the only marten species native to South India. 
Little is known about the behaviour of Nilgiri Matern because of its cryptic nature. 
They are small carnivores which mainly feed on small mammals, birds and insects. 
They are the creatures with many amazing physical features including a deep brown 
body and lemon yellow throat patch. They are listed as 'vulnerable' on the IUCN Red
 list because of the threats including habitat loss.

Sandalwood, which belongs to the genus Santalum, is found naturally in Marayoor, 
Kerala.A journey through the Marayoor's aromatic sandalwood forests will bring you 
joy and refreshment. The fragrant yellow sandalwoods are heavy, expensive, and 
sacred. The abundant growth of sandalwood trees required humid climatic conditions.
 Sandalwoods are widely used in ayurvedic medicines and other purposes. 
Sandalwood oil has huge demand both nationally and internationally, it attracts 
tourists to visit Marayoor.

Lemongrass, also called Cymbopogon, belongs to the Poaceae family. It is found 
in the Marayoor and Kanthalloor Hill ranges of Kerala. Lemongrass oil, mainly
 used for medical purposes, cosmetics, etc., cultivated by the Muthuva Tribe in 
Idukki and the Marayoor Forest Development Agency helps them in marketing 
to get better profit.

Star tortoises are one of the most beautiful creatures in the earth with a gorgeous 
star-shaped pattern over their carapace and dark blotches on the skin. They feed on 
grasses, fruits, flowers, insects, carrion and dung. During hot and dry periods they 
remain inactive without eating food. The star tortoise is classified as ' vulnerable ' on
 the Red List of IUCN. They are critically endangered because of the illegal trafficking, 
habitat loss, their long reproductive cycles and due to exotic pet trade.

Grizzled giant squirrels are large rodents of the squirrel family found in the foothills of
the elegant Western ghats. The white flecks of hair are patterned in a grizzled way 
over their greyish-brown body. As they are arboreal creatures, they scarcely spend
 time on the ground. These endemic species are listed as "near threatened" species in
 IUCN Red List. They face a multitude of threats such as Habitat loss due to rampant 
deforestation and plantation and also from predators.

Tufted Grey Langur is one among the myriad primates found in the interiors of the 
splendid Western ghats. It is also known as Madras Grey langur and the Coromandel
 sacred langur. These herbivores creatures feed mainly on leaves, fruits and flowers 
and thereby play many ecological roles including seed dispersal.They occasionally rely
 on crops cultivated by humans too. Their very long tail, which is larger than their body
 is a major highlight. Their silky hairs all over the body and thin ears make them 
special. Tufted grey langurs are listed as 'Near Threatened' in the IUCN Red list of 
Threatened Species because of illegal hunting,pet trade and habitat loss etc.

The aromatic spice plantations in Munnar is a must-see while visiting Kerala. Munnar 
being blessed with soothing climate and high altitude hills sets favourable conditions
 for the growth of Cardamom, Queen of Spices. We can observe stretches of 
cardamom plantations while enjoying walking through the hillocks covered with lushful
 greenery of cardamom plants grown under the shades of tall trees. Nevertheless, they
 are an upshot of Colonial rule in India which gained revenue through the export of 
spices grown here. The green and black cardamom are  the main two types cultivated 
here. Since Cardamom is of great importance in Kerala cuisine, it is used domestically
 and exported, producing revenue income as well as an esteem for the place.

The dried brown buds of clove holds a major share in the spice treasury of Munnar as
 it is an important ingredient in ‘Garam Masala’, the authentic spicing agent of Kerala 
cuisine. Clove plants take around 7-8 years to flower and will live for around 80 years. 
The unopened buds are collected from the trees and sun dried before consumption.
 It can be used wholly or in powdered form, suitable for both sweet and savoury dishes.
 The medicinal value of clove adds to its importance.

The picturesque of Munnar embellished with green valleys, hills, and mountains are
 incomplete with the aromatic scent of coffee plantations. Munnar being the producer 
of the best varieties of coffee in the world is a go to place for both trekkers and coffee
 lovers, thanks to Ba Abadam who brought coffee seeds from the Holy city of Mecca to
 India back in 17C. Coffee plantations in Munnar which spreads up to several hectares
 of land provides livelihood for thousands of native workers as well as contributes to the
 tourism industry. Above all, who can miss the first hand experience of sipping freshly 
brewed coffee while romancing with the exotic munnar climate?

Nutmegs are gold grown in trees. Valleys of Munnar are an adobe for not only cardamom,
 colve, pepper and coffee but Nutmegs too. Unlike other spices, Nutmegs trees are tall, 
which grows up to several inches of height, and produces nutmeg fruits. Once ripened, these 
fruits split open by themselves and thus the seed is obtained. The red net enveloping the 
seed tastes similar to the seeds and is of high demand in the spice market. The shells are 
often processed in the form of pickles while the seeds are dried and sold.

Woody plants bearing large clusters of rose-like flowers. The shoal grasslands of Munnar are
 filled with a variety of species belonging to the rhododendron genus. Its spirally arranged 
leaves have quite fascinating features like scales on the undersurface. The morphologically 
diverse genus comprises many lovely species like hymenanthes, pentathera, azaleastrum.

The large rugged antlers are native to the Indian subcontinent. The deer has a unique 
distribution as it can be found in the lobes of the Himalayas in Nepal and India and they also
 inhabit the tropical dry forests and grasslands of the western ghats. Sambars have 
developed more of a nocturnal activity pattern as a response to hunting by humans, which 
has now put them among the vulnerable in the red list. They are good swimmers and have 
highly developed senses. Sambar deers are predominantly found solitary unlike most of 
the deers.

This unique insectivorous mammal is native to the Indian subcontinent. They have a peculiar
 long lower lip and palate used for sucking up insects. You knew of sloth bears even before
 you thought you knew. Rudyard Kipling’s description of Baloo from The Jungle Book is 
consistent with the sloth bear. Unlike the sleepy old brown bear from the stories, these are 
excellent climbers, good swimmers, and can gallop faster than a running human. Their name
 is another misnomer as they don’t even hibernate!  Unfortunately, the animal is listed as 
vulnerable on the IUCN red list and is now found only in the wet tropical forest areas.

The Indian bison is the largest wild bovid alive today. Their massively built body has a head
 to body length of 10ft with height up to 6ft in males. However, the species is placed among 
the vulnerable in the red list. The Western Ghats is home to a major part of the remaining 
population. They are not found in regions of higher altitudes but generally stick to the foothills.
 It’s  might is unmatched. The fierce wild gaur is in fact the iconic spotlight star ‘Red bull’.

Bamboos are a group of evergreen perennial flowering plants. It is known for its deep roots
 and is also one of the fastest-growing plants in the world. Certain species of bamboo are 
seen to grow almost 1000mm within a day. The plant is known for protecting the soil from
 landslides and erosion.  Bamboo, like wood, is a natural composite material with a high 
strength generally similar to a strong softwood or hardwood timber. The bamboo reserves 
of Munnar could be explored en route to the Tiger Caves and Perumbankuthu waterfalls.

Blessed with a huge forest cover, Munnar is abode to the IUCN endangered wild elephants. 
The wild tuskers are seen roaming around constantly covering 40 to 50 kilometers every
 day in and around the place. These pachyderms are frequently sighted at Anakulam,
 Anayirankal, Mattupetty, and Kundala dams. The Indian wild elephants are strictly 
herbivorous and generally feed on foliage, tree barks, and edible plants. They also consume 
seedlings, culm, and lateral shoots of bamboo. In Munnar and its surroundings, they show a 
noticeable preference for vegetables like carrot, cabbage, beetroot, beans, peas, bananas,
 and sugarcane.

Eucalyptus Grandis or simply the Grandis tree is an imported species of flora from Australia. 
It is a tall tree with smooth bark, rough at the base, fibrous or flaky, grey to grey-brown.
 It has observably taken over a large part of the native vegetation of Munnar over decades. 
With the rise of the plywood industry, Grandis secured a proper deep rooted place in the 
area. On a jeep journey from Munnar to Vattavada via Mattupetty and Kundala lake, the 
majestic Grandis trees line up on both sides of the road and meander through the Pampadum 
Shola national park.

Shola forest is tropical evergreen forest in which shorter trees grow in a cluster about some
 acres in valleys. Shola forest is also found in the hill depressions at high range areas. Shola 
forest is different from grasslands that we see in the hill ranges. One can see shorter trees,
 seedlings and grasses in a Shola forest area. Hydnocarpus alpina, Isonandra stocksii, 
Gomphandra coriacea, Lasianthus  Alpina, Chionanthus ramiflorus and Mastixia arborea are
 the dominant trees that are seen mostly in Shola forest areas. Shola forest maintains its 
greenery all over the year irrespective of seasons. This helps some endangered animals to 
find their natural habitat. You can see Shola forest areas in different parts of Munnar. If you 
are lucky, you can spot animals like Tiger, Leopard, Elephant and birds like, Wood Pigeons 
and yellow throated Bulbuls in the Shola forest areas at Munnar.

The Shola Forest areas at Munnar are a fascination for nature lovers and study matter for 
geologists. The abundant wildlife wealth in these areas gives significance to these forest 
areas in ecological balance. You can plan a stay at Munnar and can visit all these places
 in your trip
ffRiskLevel:
several threatened,
 rare or endemic 
species

ffDescription:
Malabar giant squirrel (Ratufa indica) is a large tree squirrel species endemic to forests and
 woodlands in India. It is a diurnal, arboreal, and mainly herbivorous squirrel,is sight to behold
 with its regal red velvet pelt and languid tail that trails it like a cape. 

In Munnar’s remote jungles, the Malabar giant squirrel quite naturally tends to flee at the sight 
of humans, being unaccustomed to their presence. However, those found near human 
habitations are far more trusting and 
appear to be quite at home with people around them — a sight that would surely warm the 
cockles of a nature-lover’s heart.

Malabar giant squirrel is one of the largest squirrels with a head–and–body length of 25–50 cm
 (10 in–1 ft 8 in), a tail that is about the same or somewhat longer, and a weight of 1.5–2 kg 
(3.3–4.4 lb), although rarely up to 3 kg (6.6 lb).Average for both sexes is about 36 cm (1 ft 2 in)
 in head–and–body length, 45 cm (1 ft 6 in) in tail length and 1.7–1.8 kg (3.7–4.0 lb) in weight.

While trailing through the evergreen forests of Munnar, you might hear a loud series of 
whoops, and only if you are fortunate enough, you could find Nilgiri Langurs
 (Semnopithecus johnii)  with glossy black fur topped by a furry yellowish ‘halo’ at the other
 end of the whoop. Nilgiri Langur is a threatened species placed among the 25 most 
endangered anthropoids and is included in IUCN’s Red List. The richness of Western Ghats
 blessed these species with bountiful foliage, fruits and flowers but due to unethical poaching, 
destruction of habitat and misconceptions concerning the medicinal values of Langur’s flesh 
resulted in the drastic decline in the population of Nilgiri Langurs. They are also called “John
 Leaf’s Monkey”.
